comments.author: Anthony Schlessman

captions.text:
Good day. Of all the multitudes of characters
seen in the Star Wars expanded universe, the

one that is still the most badass is, of course,
Han Solo. But the close second is also, of

course, Kyle Katarn. Really, for a first person
shooter protagonist, Kyle Katarn is really

unique in that he actually has a significant
character arch over the Dark Forces games.

Now the game we're looking at today is Star
Wars: Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast, or Dark
Forces 3 1/2 or something along those lines.

Now, in this game, we actually see Kyle Katarn
not as a neophyte Jedi but rather as a bitter

outcast Jedi. Now he was not exiled from the
Jedi Order by Luke or anything, he just decided

to not continue on as a Force user and he
just sort of abandoned it. Now, in this game,

we actually get to see Kyle Katarn come to
terms with his Jedi heritage, and it is quite
entertaining to say the least.

Now, apart from the story, the gameplay for
Jedi Knight 2 is really quite excellent. Now

the graphics for this game are, quite simply,
amazing. This uses the Quake 3 Arena engine,

and it certainly shows. This game has aged
quite well to say the least. Everything looks

quite realistic, everything flows rather smoothly,
and overall, the Force powers are used a lot

more efficiently than in Jedi Knight 1. Really,
this game is in every way an improvement over
the original.

Unlike with Jedi Knight 1, this game was not
developed by LucasArts. Rather, it was developed

by Raven Software, and it definitely shows.
Like in all of the epic Raven Software games,

you get numerous weapons that are all pretty
distinct from one another. From the humble

Imperial Stormtrooper Blaster Rifle, to the
ever awesome Disruptor Rifle that allows you
to disintegrate enemies.

The level design is absolutely superb, as
one would expect from a Raven Software game.

It is anything but linear, and there are many
different passages to explore. The music for

the game is pretty bloody game; it's still
just the Star Wars score, but it has been

arranged fairly well. The enemies in the game
range from the basic Storm trooper to the

new Shadow Trooper, and that's one of the
things about this game that sets it apart

from the first. The lightsaber combat is extremely
well designed; it actually feels like a legitimate

lightsaber fight. Not a lightsaber duel, with
all the various choreographed moved, but a

legitimate fight. It's fast, it's dirty, and
you can get killed really easily. And that's

really one of the best aspects of the game.
The lightsaber combat is probably the best
it's ever going to get.

Now in addition to fighting various Dark Jedi,
you even get to fight battle droids. I'm not

talking those crappy little B-1 battle droids,
I'm talking ED-209 styled giant mechs! Really,
could this game get any better?

Wait a minute... Is that Lando?! Aww yeah.
It just got better. Yes, Lando Calrissian

shows up in this game as well, making this
game totally Lando. And you certainly do not

have to escort him at all. Overall, Jedi Knight
2 is an excellent game, and one that I highly

recommend picking up for any fan, be it one
of first person shooters or Star Wars. Because

you can't get a game more Lando than this
one. And so, this is Jon, signing off.

title: CGR Undertow - STAR WARS JEDI KNIGHT 2: JEDI OUTCAST review for PC
